audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing his research background in chemistry, mentioning a PhD and postdoctoral work in inorganic chemistry. He expresses a desire to move away from bench research and pursue a career that would broaden his perspective. He mentions joining Nature Communications as a launch editor and later moving to Scientific Reports, drawn to the idea of working on an inclusive and high-quality journal. The speaker generally speaks in a clear and professional tone. Throughout the speech there is soft background music playing that sounds inspirational, giving a sense of motivation and forward movement.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker stating that "there's no very typical day on scientific reports." He then describes his role as chief editor, overseeing a group of eight in-house editors. He explains how they oversee the editorial decision-making process and the peer review process on the journal. He mentions that these processes are managed directly by external editorial board members, who decide whether to send a manuscript out to peer review, recruit peer reviewers, and make decisions after peer review. The speaker maintains a professional and informative tone throughout.

The clip features a single male speaker discussing project enhancements and improved time to decision. The speaker then mentions "scientific reports" and the varied and satisfying nature of the role. Throughout, his tone is professional and descriptive.

The audio begins with a male speaker highlighting aspects of his work he enjoys most, specifically, working with in-house and external editors and developing teams to provide a high level of service to authors. He describes the processes as "robust" in terms of "peer review" and "editorial process." He speaks in a thoughtful and explanatory tone. He mentions building a trusted, high-quality, and inclusive journal through developing those teams and the processes of the journal. Light and uplifting background music underscores the speech.

The clip features one male speaker discussing the scientific reports and publishing research from natural and clinical sciences. He notes that editorial decisions are not based on perceived importance but that rigorous peer review ensures only high-quality, robust science is published. The speaker's tone is informative and professional.

The clip begins with a single male speaker outlining criteria for evaluating papers, emphasizing originality, data-supported conclusions, reproducibility, and contextualization within previous literature, spoken in a calm and clear tone.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing "Scientific Reports" as an "inclusive journal," clarifying that this doesn't equate to publishing all submissions, mentioning a current acceptance rate of around 48%. He emphasizes the "rigorous and robust" editorial review process overseen by external editorial board members, which ensures only high-quality science is published.

The clip begins with a male speaker providing advice to potential authors, emphasizing the need to carefully read submission guidelines and ensure compliance with relevant policies. His tone is measured and professional. The speaker then recommends ensuring the central conclusions are supported by the presented data, and paying particular attention to titles and abstracts. His tone becomes more emphatic as he highlights how titles and abstracts affect a paper's handling and review, and how they help increase its impact upon publication.

The audio features a single male speaker discussing academic publishing and editorial careers, highlighting traits such as a passion for science, openness to leaving lab work, and interest in broader subjects and writing. The speaker's tone is informative and somewhat reflective. Following this, the speaker touches upon becoming an editor, mentioning the learning curve and the necessity of resilience and time management skills. The conversation concludes with emphasizing the need for a broader passion for and interest in science and knowledge of the peer review process.
